About 30 percent of students are

admitted on merit alone.

The competition is fierce. Each student gets a score out of 900 that’s based on their grades and standardized test performance. To get into Payton on merit last year, for example, students had to score at least 898.

Most of these seats go to students from wealthier neighborhoods.

About 70 percent of students

are admitted through the “tier” system.

CPS has broken up the city into four tiers based on socioeconomic factors, like average income and area education levels. An even number of students are admitted from each of the four tiers. Students in the wealthier tiers usually must score higher to get in.

Tier One

Tier Four

Lower socioeconomic status

Higher socioeconomic status

After the regular admissions process is over, a small number of students are admitted through “principal discretion.”

Any rejected student can apply to be reconsidered. Each principal can admit five percent of their total freshmen class through this process. Last year, 164 students got a seat this way.

Most of these seats also go to students from wealthier neighborhoods.
